title: PeerQA: A Scientific Question Answering Dataset from Peer Reviews
author: Tim Baumgärtner (Ubiquitous Knowledge Processing Lab, Technical University of Darmstadt), Ted Briscoe (Mohamed bin Zayed University of Artificial Intelligence), Iryna Gurevych (Ubiquitous Knowledge Processing Lab, Technical University of Darmstadt), ...
relevance_why: The methods and findings on question answering systems and evidence retrieval could inform approaches in audio-language modeling, especially in developing tools that leverage peer-reviewed information effectively.
background: The study focuses on creating a dataset for extracting and generating answers from scientific papers based on peer review questions.
contribution: PeerQA introduces a dataset sourced from peer reviews and annotated by paper authors to facilitate question-answering systems in the scientific domain, achieving enhanced evidence retrieval and answer generation tasks.

technical_comparison.prior_work: Previous datasets in scientific QA often relied on general crowdsourced questions or did not have expert-backed answer annotations.
technical_comparison.novelty: This work utilizes real peer review questions and expert answers, improving both question contextualization and answer validity.

key_innovation: Combines peer reviews with direct author input to elevate the quality and relevance of the scientific QA dataset.
real_world_impact: By enhancing how information is extracted from scientific literature, this dataset could lead to more efficient peer review processes and greater accessibility of scientific knowledge.
limitations: The dataset is limited in size compared to general QA datasets, which may restrict its application in broader contexts.

new_terms.question answering (QA): **Question answering (QA)** systems are tools designed to automatically respond to inquiries by retrieving relevant information from a given dataset.
new_terms.evidence retrieval: **Evidence retrieval** refers to the process of identifying specific pieces of information within documents that can be used to substantiate answers to questions posed.

open_sourcing: The dataset and code are available at https://github.com/UKPLab/peerqa.
